title: 113_s1818
content:
The "Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe - Fish Springs Ranch Settlement Act" includes definitions and provisions for ratification of agreements, waiver of claims, satisfaction of claims, beneficiaries, jurisdiction, environmental compliance, and miscellaneous provisions. The Act defines key terms such as "Original Agreement" and "Agreement" related to the Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe-Fish Springs Ranch settlement. It also includes the definition of "environmental impact statement" and "final payment date." The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms related to the settlement between the Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe and Fish Springs Ranch, including "final payment date," "Fish Springs," and "Fish Springs water rights." These definitions clarify the terms used in the agreement. The curr_chunk defines terms related to the settlement between the Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe and Fish Springs Ranch, including "additional Fish Springs water rights" and "Honey Lake Valley Basin." These definitions clarify specific rights and locations mentioned in the agreement. The curr_chunk discusses the pumping and transfer of water rights from Fish Springs within the Honey Lake Valley Basin, including up to 13,000 acre feet per year. This includes specific details on the allocation of water rights and approvals for groundwater pumping. The term "record of decision" is defined as the public record of the District Manager's decision. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to the decision-making process, including "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, "Tribe" as the Pyramid Lake Paiute Tribe of Indians, and "Truckee River Operating Agreement" as an agreement negotiated for water management purposes. The curr_chunk refers to the Truckee-Carson-Pyramid Lake Water Rights Settlement Act and the Truckee River Operating Agreement. SEC. 3 of the Truckee-Carson-Pyramid Lake Water Rights Settlement Act authorizes and ratifies the Agreement, with provisions for waiver and retention of claims by the Tribe. Compliance with applicable law is ensured. SEC. 4 addresses waiver and releases of claims. In exchange for benefits outlined in the Original Agreement, the Tribe is authorized to waive rights to challenge the Project or Fish Springs water rights, including senior priority claims. The Tribe establishes senior water rights over Project or Fish Springs water rights, including claims for damages or interference with tribal water rights. Claims also include injury to lands or resources and water quality issues related to Fish Springs water rights. The Tribe asserts senior water rights over Project or Fish Springs water rights, including claims for damages or interference. Claims also cover injury to lands or resources and water quality issues related to Fish Springs water rights. The Tribe retains all claims for enforcement of the Water Banking Trust Agreement with Fish Springs, including the right to seek remedies in the U.S. District Court for the District of Nevada. They also reserve the right to assert and protect any rights against Fish Springs, subject to the waiver and release in subsection (a). In subsection (a), the Tribe retains the right to assert and protect surface or groundwater rights, establish water rights in accordance with the law, and maintain all other rights, remedies, and claims not waived in the Agreement. The Tribe retains the right to enforce its rights under various agreements and permits related to the Truckee River and Project water, as well as seek enforcement of permits issued for wastewater treatment facilities. Additionally, the Tribe can seek enforcement of permits or rights-of-way issued for the Fish Springs Project on Federal lands. The Tribe can waive all claims against the United States related to the Project and Fish Springs water rights in exchange for benefits outlined in the Agreement. This includes claims for damages, losses, or injuries related to the Project, water rights, and implementation. The curr_chunk discusses potential claims related to loss of water or water rights, interference with water, and failure to protect or acquire water resources due to the Project or Fish Springs water rights. It also mentions the record of decision, environmental impact statement, and claims by the United States as trustee. The curr_chunk discusses the United States' claims on behalf of the Tribe related to the Project, negotiation of agreements, fund usage, land acquisition, and extinguishment of claims. The Tribe retains rights and claims against the United States despite waivers and releases authorized in the Act. The Tribe retains various rights and claims against the United States, including enforcement of the Act in court, seeking enforcement of permits, and other rights not waived in the Agreement. Upon waiver and release by the Tribe and final payment by Fish Springs, the United States will act on behalf of the Tribe. Upon waiver and release by the Tribe, the United States will have no liability for the waived claims. The United States reserves the right to enforce the terms of the right-of-way across Federal lands for the Project. The waivers and releases authorized under subsections (a) and (c) shall take effect on the day Fish Springs makes the payment to the Tribe as provided in subparagraph 4.2 of the Agreement. SEC. 5. SATISFACTION OF CLAIMS.

The benefits provided to the Tribe under the Agreement and this Act shall be considered full satisfaction of all claims waived by the Tribe. Failure to execute waivers within 60 days will render the Act and Agreement null and void.

SEC. 6. BENEFICIARIES TO AGREEMENT. SEC. 6. BENEFICIARIES TO AGREEMENT.

The beneficiaries of the Agreement are limited to the parties involved, municipal water purveyors providing Project water, water purveyors using Project water for non-retail purposes, and assignees of Water Rights Credits. No third-party beneficiary status is granted except as specified. Jurisdiction over civil actions related to the Agreement, the Original Agreement, or this Act is vested in the United States District Court for the District of Nevada. The Act does not prevent the United States or the Tribe from enforcing Federal environmental laws, including the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act, Safe Drinking Water Act, Federal Water Pollution Control Act, Solid Waste Disposal Act, and related regulations. SEC. 9. MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS. This Act does not establish a standard for quantifying Federal reserved water rights or Indian tribe claims in any other legal proceedings. The Agreement, Original Agreement, and this Act do not affect water rights, claims, or entitlements of any Indian tribe other than the Tribe.
